answers.text: Battle of the Teutoburg Forest r

qas.question: Who ordered the conquest of the Germans in the 1200's BC
Who did the Romans defeat ate the Battle of the Teutoburg Forest?
What did the Romans get from the Germans?

context: Conflict between the Germanic tribes and the forces of Rome under <a0_0>Julius Caesar<a0_0/> forced major Germanic tribes to retreat to the east bank of the Rhine. <b8_0>Roman emperor <a5_0>Augustus<b8_0/><a5_0/> in <a1_0>12 BC<a1_0/> ordered the conquest of the <b9_0>Germans<b9_0/>, but the catastrophic Roman defeat at the <a2_0><a7_0>Battle of the Teutoburg Forest<a2_0/> r<a7_0/>esulted in the Roman Empire abandoning its plans to completely conquer Germany. Germanic peoples in Roman territory were culturally Romanized, and although much of Germany remained free of direct Roman rule, Rome deeply influenced the development of German society, especially the adoption of <a3_0><b10_0>Christianity<b10_0/><a3_0/> by the Germans who obtained it from the Romans. In Roman-held territories with Germanic populations, the <a4_0>Germanic and Roman peoples intermarried<a4_0/>, and Roman, Germanic, and Christian traditions intermingled. The adoption of <a6_0>Christianity<a6_0/> would later become a major influence in the development of <b11_0>a common German identity<b11_0/>.
